JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY. APRIL 1, 1962

22

EXTRA
66TH YEAR

• Kesler Elected SC President;
Lost Ballot Box causes Recount
lOutcome Reversed
By Uncounted Votes
After an emergency recount of the ballots over spring
vacation, Dick Kesler has been declared president of the
Hopkins Student Council.
Shortly after the first ballot had given a majority to
Kesler's opponent, it was discovered that the last day's returns from the Levering Hall ballot box had not been
counted. The results of this recount gave Kesler a small
majority of the total vote and reversed the election results.
When contacted at home and informed of the circumstances of his election, Kesler had the following statement
to make: "I realize that the election was a close one, but I
intend to go through with my plans as I announced in the
campaign. I hope that the whole campus can be united in
a universal improvement program."
Perrotto Promises Support

Joe Perrotto, Kesler's defeated opponent, said that
he "regretted the way things turned out," but promised
Kesler his own support and that of the 114U Committee
which he heads.
The errant ballot box,'whose loss caused the erroneous
announcement of Perrotto as S.C. president just before
vacation, has found in Levering Hall by a janitor after the
building had closed for the day. The box was brought to
N
EISENHOWER CONGRATULATES KESLER ON ELECTIO
the attention of the S.A.C. the next day but it has too late
to reverse the results at that time.
The ballots were counted during spring vacation and
Kesler and Perrotto were informed by phone of the reversed outcome. Bob Grabernathy, current president of the
council, apologized to the candidates for the mixup. Grabernathy said later in a statement to the press that the misa
